content:
The Jewish population of Sokolów Malopolski around 1900 was significant, with Jews making up a substantial percentage of the town's overall population. According to census data from the time, the total population of Sokolów Malopolski was around 6,500 people, and approximately 4,000 of those residents were Jewish.

The Jewish community in Sokolów Malopolski at the turn of the 20th century was a diverse and vibrant one, with a range of different occupations, interests, and religious affiliations. There were merchants, artisans, and farmers among the Jewish population, as well as scholars, rabbis, and religious leaders. Jews in Sokolów Malopolski were involved in a variety of cultural and religious activities, including Torah study, prayer, and charitable work.

However, the period around 1900 was also a time of significant political and social upheaval in Poland and throughout Europe. The First World War was just a few years away, and the political situation in Poland was unstable. These factors, along with the rising tide of anti-Semitism throughout Europe, would ultimately have a devastating impact on the Jewish community in Sokolów Malopolski and across Poland.
